sentences.sentence: Interest rates RBA insiders may be making the case for a higher cash rate, as Michele Bullock walks the line between public opinion and the bank's vital credibility.Reserve Bank staff members have had to make some bold forecast assumptions to keep their inflation projections on a path consistent with a 4.35 per cent cash rate.The recent run of stronger-than-expected economic data meant the bank's economists had no choice but to make upward revisions to their employment and inflation forecasts for 2024.

But they have treated this as a "mark to market" exercise and have not allowed the changes to flow through to the 2025 and 2026 numbers.Their analysis of the economic outlook shows a heavy application of judgment was overlaid on model and other analytics to keep the expected trajectory for inflation in line with the existing 2025-26 forecasts from February.Governor Michele Bullock has previously stated that the board has no tolerance for any further slippage in the timeline to return inflation to target.

Inflation is forecast to be under 3 per cent by December 2025, when it will have been above target range for four years.Any upward revision to the projected path for inflation that pushed out that timing would breach the commitment, and trigger a rate increase.Getting inflation back to target within four years is where the RBA's credibility rests.
The staff analysis of the economic outlook makes it clear that they have had to make some bold assumptions to maintain the existing forecast trajectory.

They are not hiding it in any way.The first assumption is that the household saving ratio will rise over the course of 2024 to ensure that the boost to household disposable incomes from tax cuts and stable interest rates does not translate into a pick-up in consumption.Consumer spending must stay soft to keep rates on hold, a byproduct of an economy operating beyond its capacity.
This is entirely at odds with those suggesting that the RBA should cut rates based on weak consumption growth.The second assumption that the RBA identifies as highly uncertain is productivity growth.

Despite an expectation that nominal wages growth will moderate over the course of this year, we still need to see higher productivity growth to ensure a downward trajectory for inflation.The current set of economic forecasts has factored in productivity growth returning to its long-run average in 2024 and 2025.
Given how weak productivity growth has been over the past three years, this is a big assumption.
The risks to the RBA's labour productivity forecast are all in one direction.These two forecast assumptions stand out to me among several other risks discussed in the statement on monetary policy.

I cannot make those assumptions in my forecasts, and that is a key reason why I have a 5 per cent cash rate by the end of 2024 in my central case projections.Other risks could impact my forecasts in the other direction, but my judgment is this would result in just one or two rate rises, rather than three.Over the past two months, the run of data raised a critical question for my central case projection for the Australian economy: Do I revise up growth and inflation, or do I assume a higher cash rate to keep us on the "narrow path"?
I chose the latter.The RBA board couldn't lift rates this week.
It was a bridge too far.
The market narrative had only shifted in the past few weeks.
Most forecasters had only pushed out the timing of rate cuts; just a few had moved to increases.

The financial markets were pricing in a rate rise as the next move, but only as a 5 per cent chance on the day, and only a 45 per cent chance of a 25 basis point increase at any time.The backlash would have been severe.
Don't poke the bear, particularly at the circus.

Glenn Stevens may have had the courage to fire off a pre-election rate rise in 2007, but a pre-budget increase in 2024 would cross the line from courage to stupidity.RBA staff look like they are in the process of making the case for a higher cash rate to the board and elements of the broader community.

They introduced an important concept into the policy outlook by stating that "risks to the domestic outlook are broadly balanced though the costs associated with these risks differ".The governor raised a related issue in the press conference, saying the board had discussed the merits of the timeline for returning inflation to target.
It is quite surprising that this was even up for discussion given her prior commitment to the four-year timeline.It all boils down to the risk that inflation becomes entrenched within the economy.

Entrenched inflation means one thing, and one thing only - much higher interest rates than anyone would care to comprehend right now, and a highly disruptive recession to follow.While the governor remains confident that inflation is not entrenched, I am not so sure there is room for complacency.
The Economist magazine's latest assessment of entrenched inflation has Australia ranked one out of 10 advanced economies.Governor Bullock is navigating a central banker's nightmare.

Any misstep will be dealt with severely in the court of public opinion.There is a growing body of evidence that the cash rate needs to be higher if the RBA board wants to keep the economy on the "narrow path" and ensure a return to price stability in a reasonable timeframe.While a June rate rise cannot be ruled out, another upside surprise on inflation in the Q2 CPI, released in late July, will all but guarantee a policy adjustment in August.Warren Hogan is managing director of EQ Economics and economic adviser to Judo Bank.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.

But they have treated this as a "mark to market" exercise and have not allowed the changes to flow through to the 2025 and 2026 numbers.Their analysis of the economic outlook shows a heavy application of judgment was overlaid on model and other analytics to keep the expected trajectory for inflation in line with the existing 2025-26 forecasts from February.Governor Michele Bullock has previously stated that the board has no tolerance for any further slippage in the timeline to return inflation to target. Don't poke the bear, particularly at the circus. Entrenched inflation means one thing, and one thing only - much higher interest rates than anyone would care to comprehend right now, and a highly disruptive recession to follow.While the governor remains confident that inflation is not entrenched, I am not so sure there is room for complacency. The Economist magazine's latest assessment of entrenched inflation has Australia ranked one out of 10 advanced economies.Governor Bullock is navigating a central banker's nightmare. Any misstep will be dealt with severely in the court of public opinion.There is a growing body of evidence that the cash rate needs to be higher if the RBA board wants to keep the economy on the "narrow path" and ensure a return to price stability in a reasonable timeframe.While a June rate rise cannot be ruled out, another upside surprise on inflation in the Q2 CPI, released in late July, will all but guarantee a policy adjustment in August.Warren Hogan is managing director of EQ Economics and economic adviser to Judo Bank.
